title: Graph Neural Network Aided MU-MIMO Detectors

sections.vii simulation results:
In this section, we first evaluate the posterior distribution approximation of the proposed detectors.
We then analyse the performance of our proposed detectors by comparing their SER performance with that of the state-of-the-art MP and NN based detectors. More specifically, the SER is evaluated with respect to the channel condition number, SNR, and transmit-to-receive antennas ratio. The MP detectors considered in this paper are the AMP , MMSE , BPIC 4, OAMP 2, and EP  detectors.
The weighting coefficients in the EP and GEPNet detectors are set to 0.90.90.9 and 0.70.70.7, respectively. Besides the proposed NN based GEPNet and GPICNet detectors, we also consider the state-of-the-art NN based GNN [ref]21, OAMPNet  and RE-MIMO  detectors.
Since we focus on MU-MIMO systems where the transmit-to-receive antennas ratio is high, we consider Œ±‚âúKN‚àà2 ‚âúùõºùêæùëÅ121\alpha\triangleq\frac{K}{N}\in\left[\frac{1}{2},1\right].
The proposed GEPNet and GPICNet detectors only need to be trained with Ktrain‚àà{12‚ÄãN,N}subscriptùêætrain12ùëÅùëÅK_{\rm train}\in\{\frac{1}{2}N,N\}, as discussed in the previous section. The RE-MIMO  was trained with Ktrain‚àà{12‚ÄãN,12‚ÄãN+1,‚Ä¶,N}subscriptùêætrain12ùëÅ12ùëÅ1‚Ä¶ùëÅK_{\rm train}\in\{\frac{1}{2}N,\frac{1}{2}N+1,\dots,N\}, as suggested in . The OAMPNet and GNN detectors were trained with the same number of users as in the testing phase, i.e., Ktrain=KsubscriptùêætrainùêæK_{\rm train}=K, as suggested by their authors.
We also provide the ML detection results. The ML detector was implemented by using Gurobi optimizer  to solve the quadratic minimization problem (4). Specifically, the Gurobi optimizer employs an advanced version of the widely known branch-and-cut method . Unless otherwise mentioned, 500000500000500000 channel realizations were used to compute the SER. We employ 444-QAM, 161616-QAM, and 646464-QAM modulation.
